G. L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 28, the Court may modify a prior custody judgment when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification serves the **best interests of the child**.

G. L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Determine that modification of the order is in the **best interests of the minor child** under **G. L. c. 208, § 28**, **G. L. c. 209C, § 20**, and applicable case law;

G. L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION  (pursuant to G. L. c. 208, § 28; G. L. c. 209C, § 20; and G. L. c. 215, § 6)

G. L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The current custody schedule no longer serves Emily’s **best interests**, as defined by **G. L. c. 208, § 31**, and has become **impracticable and detrimental** to her welfare due to the Defendant’s relocation.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**, and **Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996)**, the Court must focus on the child’s stability, developmental needs, schooling, and emotional well‑being when assessing any modification request.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a relocation/removal case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general custody‑modification standard case. It reiterates that the governing test is the child’s “best interests,” but it does not articulate, as a general rule for modification requests, that the court must focus specifically on stability, developmental needs, schooling, and emotional well‑being. Those factors happen to be discussed in the factual application here, but they are not framed as a required, generally applicable checklist for all modification proceedings.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). … [The judge] made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, [and] that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests….”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under **Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)**, and **Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996)**, the Court must focus on the child’s stability, developmental needs, schooling, and emotional well‑being when assessing any modification request.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn focuses on the need for explicit findings about the effects of domestic violence on the child and the batterer’s parenting ability when making custody determinations. While the opinion briefly notes that the child is doing well in school and discusses his relationship with each parent, it does not articulate a general requirement that courts, in modification proceedings, must focus on stability, developmental needs, schooling, and emotional well‑being. The case is about incorporating domestic‑violence impact into the best‑interests analysis, not about setting out the broader best‑interests factors cited in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: “It is well documented that witnessing domestic violence, as well as being one of its victims, has a profound impact on children. … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. … Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The principles articulated in **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**, **Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)**, and **Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)**, underscore that maintaining continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in determining a child’s best interests.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses the best interests standard and identifies stability, continuity of care, and minimizing disruption as key considerations, citing Adoption of Hugo among other cases. In applying the standard, the court emphasizes the harm caused by disrupting the child’s attachment and the importance of a stable, consistent caregiving environment, thereby aligning with the proposition that continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in best-interests determinations.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See Adoption of Kali, supra at 843, 847 (stability and flexible work schedule); Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 230-231 (1998)… The judge has discretion when awarding custody of a child to which we give ‘substantial deference.’”}

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The principles articulated in **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**, **Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)**, and **Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)**, underscore that maintaining continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in determining a child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly frames the custody and visitation determinations around minimizing disruption and promoting a stable, healthy environment for the children, treating this as central to their best interests. The court emphasizes the children’s bond with the primary caretaker, the need to avoid continued parental warfare, and the importance of an arrangement that minimizes disruption to their growth and development. This aligns with the proposition that continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in the best‑interests analysis, even if those exact words are not used.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: The principles articulated in **Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)**, **Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)**, and **Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998)**, underscore that maintaining continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in determining a child’s best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes stability and continuity as important factors in a child’s life, but it expressly rejects treating stability, existing bonds, or avoidance of traumatic transitions as presumptive or paramount. The court emphasizes that the best‑interests standard is flexible, that no single factor (including continuity/minimizing stress) is dispositive, and upholds a decision to disrupt an established, stable placement in favor of a different long‑term placement. Thus, Adoption of Hugo does not stand for the proposition that continuity and minimizing stress are primary factors in best‑interests determinations.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Stability in the life of a child, especially one as young as Hugo, is important, as the judge himself recognized. Custody of Two Minors, 396 Mass. 610, 617 (1986). Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development… We recognize that separating Hugo from his foster family will have negative consequences for him… While judgments in these cases are immensely difficult, we cannot say that avoiding the trauma of separation had to be the determining factor for the judge.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Continued enforcement of the current midweek overnight arrangement would conflict with Emily’s schooling, extracurricular involvement, and emotional welfare, contrary to the reasoning in **Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985)**, where the Court recognized that any custody or parenting time order must balance parental rights with the child’s best interests in light of changed circumstances.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The case does stand for the general principle that custody and relocation decisions must be based on the child’s best interests and account for changed post‑divorce circumstances, but it does not deal with midweek overnights, school disruption, extracurricular activities, or emotional welfare in the specific manner claimed. Yannas focuses on relocation and the ‘real advantage’ standard, not on modifying an existing parenting‑time schedule due to midweek conflicts. Thus, invoking Yannas for that specific scheduling proposition overstates its holding, even though it supports the broader best‑interests balancing concept.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change… and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child… Every person, parent and child, has an interest to be considered. The judicial safeguard of those interests lies in careful and clear fact-finding….”

Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.raw_text: Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.proposition: The Defendant’s out‑of‑state relocation constitutes a “material change” contemplated in **Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2016)**, requiring reevaluation of a parenting plan originally premised on geographically proximate households.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.support_reasoning: Rosen v. Rosen deals with equitable credits against child support arrearages and the statutory bar on retroactive modification under G.L. c. 119A, § 13(a). It does not address relocation, material changes in circumstances, or the need to reevaluate parenting plans premised on geographic proximity. The proposition misattributes to Rosen a relocation/material-change principle that simply is not discussed in the opinion.
Rosen v. Rosen, 90 Mass. App. Ct. 677 (2.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, despite the statutory prohibition against retroactive modification of child support judgments… a judge may — in certain very limited circumstances — grant and apply such an equitable credit to offset a child support arrearage accrued during a period when there was no pending complaint for modification.”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Judicial precedent also recognizes that modifications are appropriate where the prior order has become “unworkable” or “detrimental” to the child—see **Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)**, and **Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010)**.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: Ardizoni addresses the standard for modifying custody orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28 as requiring a “material and substantial change in the circumstances” and that any modification be in the child’s best interests. It does not articulate a distinct standard that modification is appropriate when a prior order becomes “unworkable” or “detrimental” to the child, nor does it use that terminology. The case focuses on whether sufficient evidence supported a particular split-custody arrangement, not on recognizing an ‘unworkable/detrimental’ test for modification generally.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that ‘a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred’ to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification ‘is necessary in the best interests of the children.’”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Judicial precedent also recognizes that modifications are appropriate where the prior order has become “unworkable” or “detrimental” to the child—see **Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)**, and **Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010)**.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald is about statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and the impermissibility of ordering a fit sole legal parent to relocate back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss standards for modification of prior custody orders, nor the concepts of an order becoming “unworkable” or “detrimental” to the child as grounds for modification. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that modifications are appropriate where a prior order has become unworkable or detrimental to the child.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: “The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. … As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ … After paternity was established, the judge was obligated…to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2.raw_text: Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2006)
Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2.proposition: Massachusetts law permits modification upon a showing that the change “has a significant effect on the welfare of the child.” **Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2006)**; **G. L. c. 208, § 31**.
Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2.case_name: Rodgers v. Conservation Commission of Barnstable
Schuh v. Schuh, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 202 (2.support_reasoning:
This opinion is an environmental/wetlands case involving a conservation commission’s denial of a pier permit. It does not involve domestic relations, custody, or modification standards under G. L. c. 208, § 31, nor does it discuss any requirement that a change have a “significant effect on the welfare of the child.” The proposition concerns family law modification standards, so citing Schuh v. Schuh (a different case not reflected in this text) for that rule is inaccurate in the context of this opinion.

The opinion text provided contains no discussion of child welfare or c. 208, § 31, so there is no relevant excerpt to quote.
